creator.contact: CNRS and CEREMADE (UMR CNRS 7534), University of Paris-Dauphine, Place de Lattre de Tassigny, 75775 Paris Cedex 16, France

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: We prove a generalized version of the RAGE theorem for N-body quantum systems. The result states that only bound states of systems with 0⩽n⩽N particles persist in the long time average. The limit is formulated by means of an appropriate weak topology for many-body systems, which was introduced by the second author in a previous work, and is based on reduced density matrices. This topology is connected to the weak-∗ topology of states on the algebras of canonical commutation or anti-commutation relations, and we give a formulation of our main result in this setting.

para.p: The RAGE theorem, due to Ruelle [17], Amrein-Georgescu [2] and Enss [6] is a famous result relating the long time behavior of solutions to the Schrödinger equation and the spectral properties of the corresponding self-adjoint Hamiltonian. In particular, it states that for any fixed x in the ambient Hilbert space H,

Math.text: (limit _ (T to infinity))@((1 / T) * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@((norm@(K * P _ c * e ^ (- i * t * H) * x)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(t))) = 0

para.p: where Pc is the spectral projector to the continuous spectral subspace of H, K is any compact operator and =⁢x(t)⁢e-⁢itHx is the unique (weak) solution to Schrödinger’s equation

Math.text: cases@(i * dot@(x) * t = H * x * t, [otherwise], x * 0 = x, [otherwise])

para.p: An equivalent way of formulating the same result is as follows: for every positive self-adjoint operator γ in the trace class ⁢S1(H), consider the ergodic mean

Math.text: M * T assign (1 / T) * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@(e ^ (- i * t * H) * gamma * e ^ (i * t * H) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: which is uniformly bounded in ⁢S1(H). Then, the projection ⁢PcM(T)Pc converges weakly-∗ to 0 as →T∞. Here, the operator =⁢γ(t)⁢e-⁢itHγe⁢itH is the unique (weak) solution to von Neumann’s formulation of Schrödinger’s equation

Math.text: cases@(i * dot@(gamma) * t = closed-interval@(H, gamma * t), [otherwise], gamma * 0 = gamma, [otherwise])

para.p: The previous formulation (1) corresponds to =γ⁢|x⟩⟨x|. Put differently, any weakly-∗ convergent subsequence of ⁢M(T) has a limit M∞ which is supported on the space spanned by the eigenvectors of H. It can also be proved that M∞ commutes with H, that is,

Math.text: M _ infinity = (sum _ j)@(alpha _ j * ket@(varphi _ j) * bra@(varphi _ j))

para.p: where φj is an orthonormal system of eigenvectors of H.

The RAGE theorem is a very important result in quantum mechanics. For an infinite-dimensional Hamiltonian system such as Schrödinger’s equation, strong convergence to stationary states (that is, eigenvectors of H) cannot hold in general, due to the conservation laws. The RAGE theorem states that, on the contrary, weak convergence towards stationary states holds. Hence, in this sense, only bound states persist in the long time average. By virtue of its generality, self-adjointness of H being the only hypothesis, the RAGE theorem is a fundamental tool in the spectral theory of self-adjoint operators. For instance, it is the first step towards a more precise scattering theory of quantum systems [16] and it is also often used in the study of Anderson localization [7, 12].

However, the information it provides for an interacting many-body system is often not very precise. Consider for instance three electrons in the field of a proton, described by the three-body Hamiltonian

Math.text: H _ 3 = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ 3)@(- Delta _ x _ j - 1 / absolute-value@(x _ j)) + (sum _ (1 less= j less ell less= 3))@(1 / absolute-value@(x _ j - x _ ell))

para.p: It is known that H3 has no bound state [11, 15]. The RAGE theorem therefore tells us that the ergodic mean ⁢M(T) tends weakly-∗ to zero for every initial condition γ (a trace-class operator on ⁢L2(R9)). On the other hand, the corresponding Hamiltonian H2 for two electrons has finitely many bound states [9, 10, 8] and, of course, the hydrogen atom H1 for one electron has infinitely many. The physical picture is that some of the three particles escape, whereas the rest remain in a bound state of H2 or H1, a phenomenon that is not captured at all by the RAGE theorem. The precise description of this process through scattering theory has been the object of several works [4, 18, 13]. It was proved that, asymptotically, the time-evolved wavefunction can be approximated by a sum of products of the form ⊗⁢e-⁢itλψtφ where φ is a λ-eigenfunction of H1 or H2 and ⇀ψt0. A tensor product of this form tends weakly to zero in ⁢L2(R9), which is why the weak-∗ limit of ⁢M(T) is always zero.

In this paper, we would like to prove a new general version of the RAGE theorem that retains some information on the particles that do not escape, without addressing all the details of the scattering process. This is done by using another weak topology, for which the tensor product ⊗ψtφ converges to φ, and which was introduced by the second author in [14]. In this topology, the ergodic mean will converge to states with possibly less particles, which are supported in the point spectrum of the Hamiltonians Hn for ⩽nN. This captures the principal physical ideas, even in situations where scattering is not known or not believed to hold, for instance for potentials with an arbitrarily slow decay at infinity.

In order to state our main result, let us quickly describe the notion of convergence used in [14], where all the details may be found. Let H be any separable Hilbert space and denote by HN the symmetric (or antisymmetric) N-fold tensor product, denoted by ⊗s, of H. Let Γk be a sequence of N-particle states, that is, ⩾Γk0 and =Tr(Γk)1. For instance, for a pure state =Γk⁢|Ψk⟩⟨Ψk| for a normalized ∈ΨkHN. The n-particle density matrix of Γk is obtained by taking the partial trace with respect to -Nn variables and multiplying by an appropriate normalization constant:

Math.text: (Gamma _ k) ^ n = binomial@(N, n) * (tr _ (list@(n + 1, ldots, N)))@(Gamma _ k)

para.p: The sequence Γk is said to converge geometrically to a state Γ if the reduced density matrices of Γk all converge weakly-* to those of Γ. Except if convergence holds in trace-norm, the state Γ can never be an N-particle state. It is necessary to work with states on the truncated Fock space

Math.text: F ^ (absent less= N) * H assign C direct-sum H direct-sum cdots direct-sum H ^ N

para.p: and this corresponds to the picture that some particles can be lost. For simplicity, all the states we consider in this paper are assumed to commute with the particle number, the theory for the general case is essentially the same. Such states can be written in block form as =Γ⊕G0⋯GN, and if we start with a sequence of N-body states and investigate its geometric limits, these are the only states that can be obtained.
We rephrase the previous discussion in the following:

p.text: A sequence of states {Γk}=k1∞ on HN converges geometrically to a state =Γ⊕G0⋯GN on ⁢F⩽N(H), if

Math.text: (Gamma _ k) ^ n rightharpoonup _ ast Gamma ^ n = G _ n + ((sum _ (m = n + 1)) ^ N)@(binomial@(m, n) * (tr _ (list@(n + 1, ldots, m)))@(G _ m))

p.text: weakly-∗ in the trace-class ⁢S1(Hn) for all =n0,…,N. That is, →Tr(⁢KΓk(n))Tr(⁢KΓ(n)) for every compact operator K on Hk. This notion of convergence is denoted as ⇀gΓkΓ and extended by linearity to sequences of states on the truncated Fock space ⁢F⩽N(H).

para.p: Note that the geometric limit Γ is always a state, that is, satisfies ⩾Γ0 and

Math.text: (tr _ (F ^ (absent less= N)))@(Gamma) = G _ 0 + ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ N)@((tr _ (H ^ n))@(G _ n)) = 1.

para.p: If convergence does not hold in ⁢S1(HN), then the final state has to live over spaces with less particles, but its trace is always equal to one. If all the particles are lost, then Γ is the vacuum state =Γ⊕10⋯0. It is proved in [14, Lemma 3] that every sequence of states Γk has a geometrically convergent subsequence.
We are now able to state our main result. We consider an abstract many-body Hamiltonian of the form

Math.text: H _ n = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(h _ j) + (sum _ (1 less= j less ell less= n))@(w _ (j * ell))

para.p: acting on the n-particle space Hn (for us symmetric or antisymmetric). Here h is a given self-adjoint operator acting on the one-particle space H and hj acts on the jth factor. On the other hand, w is a self-adjoint operator on the two particle space H2 and w⁢jℓ acts on the jth and ℓth factors. We make rather general assumptions on w in order to give a proper meaning to Hn for all n. As will be clear from the rest of the paper, these can be weakened in specific examples or if one is only interested in a particular =nN. We assume that

equation.text: h is bounded from below (without loss of generality >h1)

para.p: and that

equation.text: |w| is infinitesimally form bounded with respect to +h1h2

para.p: which means that

Math.text: varepsilon * (h _ 1 + h _ 2) - C _ varepsilon less= w less= varepsilon * (h _ 1 + h _ 2) + C _ varepsilon

para.p: for all >ε0. Under these assumptions, Hn is bounded from below and may be realized as a self-adjoint operator for all n, by the method of Friedrichs.

p.text: In addition to (5) and (6), assume that for every compact operator K on H
is compact on H2. Let ⩾Γ0 with =Tr(Γ)1 be a state on the (symmetric or antisymmetric) N-particle space HN. Then, the ergodic mean

Math.text: (1 / T) * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))

p.text: has geometrically convergent subsequences as →T∞, and, for every such sequence, the limit is a convex combination of projections to eigenspaces of the n-body Hamiltonians Hn for 0⩽n⩽N.

para.p: If we consider a sequence of times →Tk∞ for which

Math.text: (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T _ k))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t) * g@(rightharpoonup) * M _ infinity) = G _ 0 direct-sum cdots direct-sum G _ N

para.p: the result states that

Math.text: G _ n = (sum _ j)@(alpha _ (list@(n, j)) * ket@(varphi _ (list@(n, j))) * bra@(varphi _ (list@(n, j))))

para.p: where {φn,j}⩾j1 is an orthonormal system of eigenvectors of the n-body operator Hn. By definition, geometric convergence means that the density matrices converge

Math.text: (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T _ k))@((e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N)) ^ n * differential-d@(t) * ast@(rightharpoonup) * (M _ infinity) ^ n) = ((sum _ (m = n)) ^ N)@(binomial@(m, n) * (tr _ (list@(n + 1, ldots, m)))@(G _ m))

para.p: weakly-* in the trace-class for all =n0,…,N. Let us emphasize that, because of the partial traces, the M∞(n) are in general not supported on the point spectrum of Hn. The density matrix M∞(n) should not be confused with the restriction Gn of the state M∞ to the n-particle space.

The condition (8) on w ensures that the interaction between a particle that stays and a particle that escapes vanishes in a weak sense. A condition of this type is clearly necessary to be sure that the remaining n particles are described by the Hamiltonian Hn when the other -Nn escape. The operator :=B⁢(+h1h2)-/12w(+h1h2)-/12 is always bounded by Assumption (6). However, in the applications, it is usually not compact. The picture is that w only decays in one direction and it is necessary to multiply by one compact operator K in another variable as in (8) to make ⁢⊗K1B and ⁢⊗1KB compact .

Our theorem is stated for any initial datum Γ, possibly with an infinite energy. However, our proof does use the conservation of energy for smooth initial data. It is an interesting open problem to derive a similar result when h is not bounded from below. We will make more comments on this below.
We also remark that the exact same theorem holds if the ergodic mean is replaced by

Math.text: (1 / T) * (integral _ R)@(chi * (t / T) * e ^ (- i * H _ N * t) * Gamma * e ^ (i * H _ N * t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: where χ is any nonnegative function such that =∫R⁢χ(t)dt1.

subsection.title: Reformulation in terms of the CAR and CCR algebras

para.p: Theorem 1 has a natural extension to the Fock space and the associated algebra of canonical (anti-) commutation relations (see [5] for a detailed introduction). This extension is based on the observation (see [14, Remark 2.1]) that for the rank-one operator

Math.text: K = ket@(f _ 1 tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s f _ n) * bra@(g _ 1 tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s g _ n)

para.p: geometric convergence of ∈Γk⁢S1(F⩽N) just means that

Math.text: Tr@(K * (Gamma _ k) ^ n) = list@(g _ 1 tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s g _ n, ((Gamma _ k) ^ n * f _ 1) tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s f _ n)
Tr@(K * (Gamma _ k) ^ n)
absent = list@(g _ 1 tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s g _ n, ((Gamma _ k) ^ n * f _ 1) tensor-product _ s cdots tensor-product _ s f _ n)
absent = (Tr _ F)@(a ^ * * f _ 1 * cdots * a ^ * * f _ n * a * g _ 1 * cdots * a * g _ n * Gamma _ k)
absent = (Tr _ F)@(a ^ * * f _ 1 * cdots * a ^ * * f _ n * a * g _ 1 * cdots * a * g _ n * Gamma _ k)

para.p: converges. Here, ⁢a*(f),⁢a(f) denote, respectively, bosonic or fermionic creation and annihilation operators, depending on whether ⊗s is the symmetric or antisymmetric tensor product.We thus have:

p.text: Let ∈A{⁢CCR(H),⁢CAR(H)} be the C*-subalgebra of the bounded operators of ⁢F(H) satisfying canonical commutation relations, if ⁢F(H) is the symmetric Fock-space, or anti-commutation relations, if ⁢F(H) is the anti-symmetric Fock-space. Denote by ΠN the projection of ⁢F(H) to HN and let ∈ρA′ be a normal state on A, that is =⁢ρ(A)Tr(⁢ΓρA) for some ∈Γρ⁢S1(F), satisfying =[Γρ,ΠN]0 for all ∈NN. Then the ergodic mean

Math.text: mu _ T * A assign (1 / T) * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@(rho * e ^ (i * H * t) * A * e ^ (- i * H * t) * differential-d@(t))

p.text: has weakly-∗ convergent subsequences subsequences as →T∞ and, for every such sequence, the limit state is normal. For the density operator Γ∞ of this state, ⁢ΠNΓ∞ΠN is a convex combination of projections to eigenspaces of HN for all ⩾N1.

para.p: The existence of weakly-∗ convergent subsequences Tk follows from the fact that A is separable and the Banach-Alaoglu theorem. By a diagonal argument we may additionally assume that

Math.text: (mu _ T _ k) ^ N * A assign mu _ T _ k * Pi _ N * A * Pi _ N to (mu _ infinity) ^ N * A

para.p: for some (unnormalized) state ∈μ∞NA′ and every ∈NN.

The action of ⁢ΠNAΠN on HN is completely determined by the action of operators of the form (10) with ⩽nN: For the fermionic case this is an immediate consequence of the commutation relations and the fact that =⁢KΠN0 if >nN; For the bosonic case one uses additionally that on HN the Weyl-operators may be expressed as convergent power series in creation and annihilation operators (see [5, chapter 9]). Thus ⁢ΠNAΠN is generated by operators of the form ⊗sK1 with compact operators K on Hn, ⩽nN. This shows that weak-∗ convergence of μTkN is equivalent to geometric convergence of the sequence ⁢ΠNM(Tk)ΠN of ergodic means with =⁢M(0)Γρ. Thus, the geometric limit satisfies =⁢μ∞N(A)Tr(⁢AM∞N) for some ∈MN∞⁢S1(F⩽N). Using that =⁢μT([ΠN,A])0 by hypothesis, and that =∥μNTk∥A′∥⁢ΠNΓρΠN∥S1 is independent of Tk, we obtain

Math.text: mu _ infinity * A assign (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu _ T _ k * A) = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(((sum _ (N = 0)) ^ infinity)@((mu _ T _ k) ^ N * A)) = ((sum _ (N = 0)) ^ infinity)@((Tr _ F)@(A * (M ^ N) _ infinity))

para.p: Consequently, =Γ∞∑=N0∞M∞N and, by Theorem 1, ⁢ΠnM∞NΠn is a convex combination of projections to eigenspaces of Hn. ∎

A typical example to which our result applies is that of a non-relativistic system of N fermions or bosons, for which the interaction w is a function of the relative position of the particles, that tends to zero at infinity in a weak sense.

p.text: Let =H⁢L2(Rd), =h+-Δ⁢V(x)e and w be the multiplication operator by an even function ⁢w(-x1x2). We assume that =V+f1f2 and that =w+f3f4 where ∈fi⁢Lpi(Rd) for some max(1,/d2)<pi<∞, or ∈fi⁢L∞(Rd) and →fi0 at infinity. Then Theorem 1 holds for the many-body Hamiltonian

Math.text: H _ N = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ N - Delta _ x _ j) + V * x _ j + (sum _ (1 less= j less ell less= N))@(w * (x _ j - x _ ell))

para.p: Under the assumptions of the statement, ⁢(-1Δ)-/12V(x)(-1Δ)-/12 and ⁢(-1Δ)-/12w(x)(-1Δ)-/12 are compact on ⁢L2(Rd) [3, Chap 8], hence the hypothesis (5), (6) are satisfied and >h1 for an appropriate choice of e.

The verification of (8) is more involved, the intuition however is rather simple. It relies on the fact that ⁢(+h1h2)-/12w(+h1h2)-/12 is compact in the relative coordinate -x1x2 parametrizing the subspace =V{∈(x1,x2)R⁢2d:=+x1x20}, i.e. its action on the space ⁢L2(V) is compact. This, together with the fact that ⊗K1 is compact in the direction ×Rd{0} parametrized by x1 and =⊕(×Rd{0})VR⁢2d, implies that the product is compact. More precisely, the property we use is the content of the following lemma, which we prove in Appendix A.

p.text: There exist compact operators Kj on ⁢L2(V) and bounded operators Bj on ⁢L2(V⟂) such that

Math.text: (h _ 1 + h _ 2) ^ (- 1 / 2) * w * (h _ 1 + h _ 2) ^ (- 1 / 2) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(K _ j tensor-product _ V B _ j)

p.text: and the sum converges in the operator-norm.

para.p: The notation ⊗V emphasizes that the tensor product of operators is induced by =⁢L2(R⁢2d)⁢⊗⁢L2(V)L2(V⟂). The property (11) is known as V-semicompactness and implies hypothesis (8) by [1, Proposition 9.2.2].

The argument is as follows: It is clearly sufficient to prove that ⁢(⊗K1)(⊗VKj1) is compact for every j. Then, since Hilbert-Schmidt operators are dense in the compact operators, it suffices to show that :=C⁢(⊗A1)(⊗VB1) is compact (and actually Hilbert-Schmidt) for operators ∈A⁢S2(⁢L2(Rd)), ∈B⁢S2(⁢L2(V)). To prove this, let ⁢a(x,x′), ⁢b(v,v′) be the integral kernels of A and B, respectively. The operator C acts of ∈ψ⁢L2(×Rdx1Rdx2) as
So C is an integral operator, whose kernel is easily seen to be in ⁢L2(R⁢4d). ∎
If w and V decay fast enough at infinity, the existence of scattering [16, 4, 18, 13] means that there exists vectors ψn,j such that

Math.text: (limit _ (t to + infinity))@((norm@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Psi - ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@((sum _ j)@((e ^ (- i * lambda _ (list@(n, j)) * t) * e ^ (i * t * Delta _ (R ^ (d * (N - n)))) * psi _ (list@(n, j))) tensor-product varphi _ (list@(n, j)))))) _ (L ^ 2 * R ^ (d * N))) = 0

para.p: where =⁢Hnφn,j⁢λn,jφn,j. Furthermore, asymptotic completeness states that one can prepare the initial datum Ψ such as to get any chosen ψn,j in the large time limit. The convergence (12) implies that

Math.text: e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * ket@(Psi) * bra@(Psi) * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * g@(rightharpoonup) * ((tensor-product _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@((sum _ j)@((norm@(psi _ (list@(n, j)))) ^ 2 * ket@(varphi _ (list@(n, j))) * bra@(varphi _ (list@(n, j)))))

para.p: geometrically. Hence, in this case, the coefficients in (9) are =αn,j||ψn,j||2. Asymptotic completeness therefore tells us that any combination G0,…,GN of the eigenvectors of the n-particles Hamiltonians Hn may be obtained in the geometric limit. We do not know if the same property is true under the more general assumptions of Theorem 1.
Results similar to Corollary 3 hold for Schrödinger operators with magnetic fields, for pseudo-relativistic operators, etc. We do not state them here for shortness.
The rest of the paper will be devoted to the proof of Theorem 1.

Let Γ be a state on the N-particle space HN and →Tk∞ be a sequence of times such that the ergodic means ⁢M(Tk), with initial condition =⁢M(0)Γ, converge geometrically to a limit =M∞⊕=n0NGn. Such a sequence exists for every Γ by [14, Lemma 3].

The proof of Theorem 1 proceeds by showing that M∞ is left invariant by the Hamiltonian :=H⊕=n0NHn (with =H00 and =H1h) on the truncated Fock space =F⩽N⊕=n1NCHn. That is, we have =M∞⁢e-⁢iHtM∞e⁢iHt and thus ≡⁢e-⁢itHnGne⁢itHnGn, for every ∈tR. Consequently, the eigenspaces of Gn are Hn-invariant. For a non-zero eigenvalue of Gn, the eigenspace has finite dimension and is thus a direct sum of eigenspaces of Hn.

The first step to proving invariance of M∞ is to note that, for every >s0, the sequence ⁢e-⁢isHNM(Tk)e⁢isHN also converges to M∞ geometrically. This holds because geometric convergence is controlled by the trace-norm and

Math.text: e ^ (- i * s * H _ N) * M * T _ k * e ^ (i * s * H _ N) = (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T _ k))@(e ^ (- i * (t + s) * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * (t + s) * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))
e ^ (- i * s * H _ N)
M * T _ k * e ^ (i * s * H _ N) = (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T _ k))@(e ^ (- i * (t + s) * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * (t + s) * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))
absent = (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ s) ^ (T _ k + s))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))
absent = (1 / T _ k) * ((integral _ s) ^ (T _ k + s))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))

absent = M * T _ k + (underbrace@((1 / T _ k) * (((integral _ T _ k) ^ (T _ n + s))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t)) - ((integral _ 0) ^ s)@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))))) _ (absent less= ((2 * s) / T _ k) * [ in ] * S _ 1)

absent = M * T _ k + (underbrace@((1 / T _ k) * (((integral _ T _ k) ^ (T _ n + s))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t)) - ((integral _ 0) ^ s)@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * Gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ N) * differential-d@(t))))) _ (absent less= ((2 * s) / T _ k) * [ in ] * S _ 1)
g@(rightharpoonup) * M _ infinity
g@(rightharpoonup) * M _ infinity

para.p: Having established this, we would like to prove that also

Math.text: e ^ (- i * s * H _ N) * M * T _ k * e ^ (i * s * H _ N) = e ^ (- i * s * H) * M * T _ k * e ^ (i * s * H) * g@(rightharpoonup) * e ^ (- is * H) * M _ infinity * e ^ (is * H)

para.p: As the left hand side depends only on HN and the right may depend on H on all the sectors with ⩽nN particles, this will certainly not be true for arbitrary Hamiltonians on Fock space. In fact, the proof of (14) will depend crucially both on the properties of H and the sequence ⁢M(Tk).

Using the particular form of the sequence ⁢M(Tk) we can reduce the proof of (14) to sequences of bounded energy. That is, let eN be such that >+HNeN1 and assume the initial condition =⁢M(0)Γ satisfies

Math.text: Tr@((H _ N + e _ N) ^ (1 / 2) * Gamma * (H _ N + e _ N) ^ (1 / 2)) less E

para.p: for some constant >E0. Then, since e-⁢itHN commutes with HN and preserves the trace-norm, we have

for every ∈kN. Since any initial condition =⁢M(0)Γ can be approximated to arbitrary precision by states of finite energy, it is sufficient to prove (14) for sequences satisfying (15), by virtue of the following lemma.

p.text: There exists a constant c, depending only on N, such that for every sequence {γk}=k1∞ in ⁢S1(HN) that converges geometrically to ∈γ⁢S1(F⩽N) and satisfies <||γk||⁢S1(HN)ε we have <||γ||⁢S1(F⩽N)⁢cε.

para.p: Since the trace-class is the dual of the compact operators, we have

Math.text: (norm@(gamma ^ n)) _ (S _ 1 * H ^ n) = (supremum _ (K * [compact, ] * norm@(K) = 1))@((limit _ (k to infinity))@(absolute-value@((Tr _ (H ^ n))@(K * (gamma _ k) ^ n))))
(norm@(gamma ^ n)) _ (S _ 1 * H ^ n)
absent = (supremum _ (K * [compact, ] * norm@(K) = 1))@((limit _ (k to infinity))@(absolute-value@((Tr _ (H ^ n))@(K * (gamma _ k) ^ n))))
absent = binomial@(N, n) * (supremum _ (norm@(K) = 1))@((limit _ (k to infinity))@(absolute-value@((Tr _ (H ^ N))@((K tensor-product 1 _ (N - n)) * gamma _ k)))) less binomial@(N, n) * varepsilon
absent = binomial@(N, n) * (supremum _ (norm@(K) = 1))@((limit _ (k to infinity))@(absolute-value@((Tr _ (H ^ N))@((K tensor-product 1 _ (N - n)) * gamma _ k)))) less binomial@(N, n) * varepsilon

para.p: Now =γ⊕=n0NGn is completely determined by its reduced density matrices, explicitly (cf. [14, Lemma 1.1]),

Math.text: G _ n = gamma ^ n + ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (N - n))@((- 1) ^ j * binomial@(n + j, n) * (Tr _ (list@(n + 1, dots, n + j)))@(gamma ^ (n + j)))

para.p: which proves the claim. ∎
It will often be useful to state the energy bound using a Hamiltonian without interaction. Let

Math.text: (H ^ 0) _ n assign ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(h _ j) > 1

para.p: and

Math.text: S _ (list@(1, H ^ 0)) * H ^ n assign conditional-set@(gamma element-of S _ 1 * H ^ n, (norm@(square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) * gamma * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n))) _ S _ 1 less infinity)

para.p: This space has a natural norm given by :=||γ||+||γ||S1∥⁢H0nγH0n∥S1. Using Hn instead of H0n gives an equivalent norm, because of the inequalities (7). We also define

Math.text: S _ (list@(1, H ^ 0)) * F ^ (absent less= N) assign conditional-set@(gamma element-of S _ 1 * F ^ (absent less= N), (norm@(square-root@(H ^ 0) * gamma * square-root@(H ^ 0))) _ S _ 1 less infinity)

para.p: with =H0⊕=n0NH0n, =H000. It will be important that geometric convergence preserves such energy estimates. The following lemma proves that the unit ball of ⁢S1,H0(F⩽N) is closed under geometric convergence. This is the only step in the proof of Theorem 1 for which positivity of H0n is essential.

p.text: Let {γk}=k1∞ in ⁢S1,H0(F⩽N) be a bounded sequence that converges geometrically to γ. Then for every ⩽nN

Math.text: square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) * (gamma _ k) ^ n * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) rightharpoonup _ * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) * gamma ^ n * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n)

para.p: By linearity, it is sufficient to prove the claim for ∈γk⁢S1,H0(HN). For any ⩽nN we have

Math.text: 0 less= ((H ^ 0) _ n tensor-product 1 _ (H ^ (N - n))) * ((H ^ 0) _ N) ^ (- 1) = 1 - (1 _ (H ^ n) tensor-product (H ^ 0) _ (N - n)) * ((H ^ 0) _ N) ^ (- 1) less= 1

para.p: because ⩾Hn01. Thus, for an arbitrary ∈η⁢S1,H0(HN),

absent less= binomial@(N, n) * (norm@((square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) tensor-product 1) * eta * (square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) tensor-product 1))) _ S _ 1

absent less= binomial@(N, n) * (norm@(square-root@((H ^ 0) _ N) * eta * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ N))) _ S _ 1

para.p: So ⁢H0nγk(n)H0n is uniformly bounded in ⁢S1(Hn) and there exists a subsequence such that

Math.text: square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) * (gamma _ k) ^ n * square-root@((H ^ 0) _ n) rightharpoonup _ * (widetilde@(gamma)) ^ n

para.p: Now for every compact operator K on Hn we have

Math.text: absent = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(Tr@(((H ^ 0) _ n) ^ (- 1 / 2) * K * (gamma _ k) ^ n * ((H ^ 0) _ n) ^ (1 / 2)))
absent = Tr@(K * gamma ^ n)
absent = Tr@(K * gamma ^ n)

para.p: whence =~γ(n)⁢H0nγ(n)H0n. ∎

The reduction of the problem to sequences of bounded energy in step 2 will now allow us to study the sequence ⁢e-⁢isHNM(Tk)e⁢isHN via the differential equation it satisfies. If ⁢γ(t) is a solution to the von Neumann equation (2), its reduced density matrices (formally) satisfy the finite BBGKY hierarchy

Math.text: i * (d / (d * t)) * gamma ^ n * t = closed-interval@(H _ n, gamma ^ n * t) + (n + 1) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((Tr _ (n + 1))@(closed-interval@(w _ (list@(j, n + 1)), gamma ^ (n + 1) * t)))

para.p: Note, however, that the equation has no clear meaning (not even in a weak sense) if w is not bounded, due to the partial trace. If w is a bounded operator →⁢D((H20)α)H2 for some >α0, this problem can be handled by considering only initial conditions satisfying <Tr(⁢(HN0)αγ(HN0)α)E, but to deal with potentials that are only H20–form-bounded we will have to define a modified equation, that is equivalent to the original one for bounded w.

theorem.title: Proposition 7 (Well-posedness of the truncated BBGKY hierarchy).

p.text: For every

p.text: the family of reduced density matrices

ref.title: (17) ‣ (1) ‣ Proposition 7 (Well-posedness of the truncated BBGKY hierarchy). ‣ Step 3. ‣ 2. Proof of Theorem 1 ‣ A many-body RAGE theorem

p.text: converge geometrically,

para.p: Note that =γ(+N1)0 and this is a triangular system, which can be solved starting with =⁢γ(N)(t)⁢e-⁢itHNγ(N)e⁢itHN. This immediately gives us uniqueness, for assume we have two solutions with ⁢γ(n)(0)=γ(n)=⁢θ(n)(0), then =⁢γ(N)(t)⁢θ(N)(t). If ∈γ(N),θ(N)⁢L∞(R,S1,H0n) this then implies =⁢γ(-N1)(t)⁢θ(-N1)(t).

We now check that =⁢γ(t)(n)(⁢e-⁢itHγe⁢itH)(n) is indeed a solution. By linearity, we may restrict to initial conditions in ∈γ⁢S1,H0(HN). Since both ⁢(+HNeN)/12(HN0)-/12 and ⁢(HN0)/12(+HNeN)-/12 are bounded, due to hypothesis (6), we have ⁢γ(t)=⁢γ(t)(N)∈⁢L∞(R,⁢S1,H0(HN)). Equation (16) then implies that ∈⁢γ(t)(n)⁢L∞(R,⁢S1,H0(Hn)).
Now assume for a moment that w is bounded and let

Math.text: W _ n assign (sum _ (1 less= j less= n less ell less= N))@(w _ (j * ell))

para.p: be the interaction of the first n particles with the remaining -Nn. Then we have

Math.text: H _ N = H _ n tensor-product 1 _ (H ^ (N - n)) + 1 _ (H ^ n) tensor-product H _ (N - n) + W _ n

para.p: and we can write ⁢γ(t)(N) using Duhamel’s formula,

Math.text: gamma * t ^ N = e ^ (- i * t * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (- i * t * H _ n) * gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ n) * e ^ (i * t * H _ (N - n))
gamma * t ^ N = absent
e ^ (- i * t * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (- i * t * H _ n) * gamma * e ^ (i * t * H _ n) * e ^ (i * t * H _ (N - n))

- i * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * closed-interval@(W _ n, gamma * s ^ N) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * differential-d@(s))

- i * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * closed-interval@(W _ n, gamma * s ^ N) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ (N - n)) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * differential-d@(s))

para.p: (with the 1⊗ omitted for shortness). This implies that

Math.text: gamma * t ^ n - e ^ (- i * t * H _ n) * gamma ^ n * e ^ (i * t * H _ n)
gamma * t ^ n - e ^ (- i * t * H _ n) * gamma ^ n * e ^ (i * t * H _ n)
= - i * binomial@(N, n) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * (Tr _ (list@(n + 1, dots, N)))@(closed-interval@(W _ n, gamma * s ^ N)) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * differential-d@(s))
= - i * binomial@(N, n) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * (Tr _ (list@(n + 1, dots, N)))@(closed-interval@(W _ n, gamma * s ^ N)) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * differential-d@(s))

= - i * (n + 1) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * (Tr _ (n + 1))@(closed-interval@(w _ (list@(j, n + 1)), gamma * s ^ (n + 1))) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * d * s))

= - i * (n + 1) * ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(e ^ (- i * (t - s) * H _ n) * (Tr _ (n + 1))@(closed-interval@(w _ (list@(j, n + 1)), gamma * s ^ (n + 1))) * e ^ (i * (t - s) * H _ n) * d * s))

para.p: This gives (17) as ⁢h+n1/12γ(+n1)h+n1/12 is trace-class. In order to account for unbounded interactions, let :=wδ⁢(+⁢δH201)-/12w(+⁢δH201)-/12 for >δ0, which is bounded by hypothesis (6). We clearly have
in the strong topology of operators on H2. Hence, the constant Cε of equation (7) may be chosen in such a way that the inequalities hold for all 0<δ⩽1. Then, for an appropriate choice of ⩾eN0,

Math.text: ((H _ N) ^ 0 + (sum _ (1 less= j less ell less= N))@((w ^ delta) _ (j * ell)) + e _ N) ^ (- 1 / 2) colon H ^ N to D * (H _ N) ^ 0 ^ (1 / 2)

para.p: is bounded, uniformly in δ. This implies that, as operators on ⁢D((HN0)/12),

Math.text: (limit _ (delta to 0))@(((H _ N) ^ 0 + (sum _ (1 less= j less ell less= N))@((w ^ delta) _ (j * ell)) + e _ N) ^ (- 1)) = (H _ N + e _ N) ^ (- 1)

para.p: strongly. This in turn implies that the unitary groups Uδ generated by these operators also converge in the strong operator topology on ⁢D((HN0)/12). So, for ∈γS1,H0, we have

Math.text: (limit _ (delta to 0))@((H _ N) ^ 0 ^ (1 / 2) * U _ delta * t * gamma) = (H _ N) ^ 0 ^ (1 / 2) * e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * gamma

para.p: in trace-norm. We thus have, using (16), that

Math.text: (limit _ (delta to 0))@((U _ delta * t * gamma * U _ delta * t ^ *) ^ n) = gamma ^ n * t

para.p: in ⁢S1,H0(Hn). As wδ is bounded, the left hand side solves (17) with this interaction. To take the limit on the right hand side of (17) observe that

Math.text: (limit _ (delta to 0))@((Tr _ (n + 1))@(L _ (j * n)) * open-interval@(w ^ delta, gamma ^ (n + 1))) = (Tr _ (n + 1))@(L _ (j * n)) * open-interval@(w, gamma ^ (n + 1))

para.p: in the space of operators for which ⁢(Hn0)-/12A(Hn0)-/12 is trace-class. As S1,H0 is obviously contained in this space, this shows that ⁢γ(t)(n) is indeed a solution.

We now prove the continuous dependence on the initial condition, item (2). Since we have already proved uniqueness, it is sufficient to show that the geometric limit of =⁢γk(t)⁢e-⁢itHγke⁢itH is a solution of (17). On the space HN this is trivial, since for any compact operator K, :=⁢K(t)⁢e⁢itHNKe-⁢itHN is also compact and thus

Math.text: (limit _ (k to infinity))@(Tr@(K * e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * gamma _ k * e ^ (i * t * H _ N))) = Tr@(K * e ^ (- i * t * H _ N) * gamma _ infinity * e ^ (i * t * H _ N))

para.p: for every ∈tR. Now let <mN and assume that ⇀*⁢γk(t)(n)⁢γ∞(t)(n) in ⁢S1(Hn) for every ∈tR and =n+m1,⁢…N. Then, we have for every compact operator K on Hm

Math.text: (i / (m + 1)) * ((tr _ (H ^ m))@(K * gamma _ k * t ^ m) - (Tr _ (H ^ m))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ m) * K * gamma _ k * 0 ^ m * e ^ (i * t * H _ m)))
(i / (m + 1)) * ((tr _ (H ^ m))@(K * gamma _ k * t ^ m) - (Tr _ (H ^ m))@(e ^ (- i * t * H _ m) * K * gamma _ k * 0 ^ m * e ^ (i * t * H _ m)))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@((Tr _ (H ^ (m + 1)))@(((K * (t - s)) tensor-product _ s 1) * L _ (j * m) * open-interval@(w, gamma ^ (m + 1))) * d * s))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ t)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@((Tr _ (H ^ (m + 1)))@(((K * (t - s)) tensor-product _ s 1) * L _ (j * m) * open-interval@(w, gamma ^ (m + 1))) * d * s))

para.p: It is clearly sufficient to prove convergence for K in a dense set of compact operators, so we may assume that =⁢K(-ts)⁢~K(-ts)(Hm)-/12 with compact ~K. For such an operator K, the integrand is uniformly bounded, and we will show that it converges pointwise. Using Lemma 6, the induction hypothesis gives us
It is thus enough to prove that
where =⁢~Kj(-ts)⁢~K(-ts)(Hm0)-/12hj/12, is compact. Denote by :S→H⊗+m1H+m1 the symmetrization operator. Hypothesis (8) guarantees that
is compact for any compact operator L. Hence, it is sufficient to show that

Math.text: (((widetilde@(K)) _ j * (t - s)) tensor-product 1) * (h _ (m + 1) * h _ j) ^ (- 1 / 2) * (h _ j + h _ (m + 1)) ^ (1 / 2) = ((sum _ (l = 1)) ^ infinity)@(L _ l tensor-product B _ l)

para.p: as a norm-convergent sum, with bounded operators Bl on H and compact operators Ll on Hm. Since hj and h+m1 commute, we have
and because 0</(-1hm-1)(+1hj-1)<1 we can write this using the convergent power series of (-1x)-/12 on <|x|1, which gives the desired form.
We have thus shown that ⁢γk(t)(m) converges weakly-* to the right hand side of equation (17) with =⁢γ(+mj)(t)(⁢e-⁢itHγ∞e⁢itH)(+mj), which proves the claim by the uniqueness of solutions to (17). ∎

This completes the proof of Theorem 1. To summarize: We noted that the Theorem is implied by invariance of the limit state M∞ under H. As a first step we then showed that this holds if the limit of the time-evolved sequence is the evolved limit state (equation (14)). In the second step we reduced the problem to considering initial conditions with bounded energy, and thus to proving (14) for sequences of uniformly bounded energy, i.e. satisfying (15). The final step consisted in studying the BBGKY-hierarchy satisfied by the reduced density matrices under the condition of finite energy, in its weak form (17). We proved uniqueness of solutions to this equation in Proposition 7. Additionally, we proved that that geometric convergence for the initial conditions, together with a uniform energy bound, implies geometric convergence of the corresponding solutions at any finite time. This gives (14) for the sequence ⁢M(Tk) of ergodic means and thus Theorem 1.

p.text: Instead of studying the evolution equation for the density matrices as in step 3, one could also study the dual evolution on the space of operators that we test against. The condition that needs to be verified is that this space is invariant under conjugation by e-⁢itH. Geometric convergence of γk is defined via convergence of Tr(⁢⊗K1γk), so the natural space of operators would be ⊗K1, where K is compact on Hn for some ⩽nN. However, this space will in general not be invariant under e-⁢itH. With a bound on the energy of the sequence γk one can instead consider operators of the form ⊗A1 such that A is (Hn0)/12-relatively compact. The space spanned by such operators is invariant by a reasoning similar to that applied in part two of Proposition 7.

The picture is that the map ↦γ⁢e-⁢itHγe⁢itH is not continuous with respect to the geometric topology on ⁢S1(F⩽N), it is however continuous for a similarly defined topology on the energy space ⁢S1,H0(F⩽N). This is sufficient to obtain Theorem 1, since the sequence ⁢M(Tk) can be uniformly approximated in that space.

para.p: Recall the notation :=V{∈(x1,x2)×RdRd:=+x1x20} and parametrize this subspace by the coordinate =v-x1x2. We will begin by showing that

Math.text: (1 - Delta _ x _ 1 - Delta _ x _ 2) ^ (- 1 / 2) * w * v * (1 - Delta _ v) ^ (- 1 / 2) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(K _ j tensor-product _ V B _ j)

para.p: with compact Kj and bounded Bj.

Let ξ denote the conjugate Fourier-variable to v and ζ that to :=v⟂+x2x1. Let =⁢η(ξ,ζ)(+1⁢2ξ2⁢2ζ2)-/12, so (-1Δ)-/12 is just the Fourier-multiplier by η. Since η tends to zero at infinity, there exist functions ⁢fj(ξ),⁢gj(ζ) with compact support, such that →→k∞∑=j1m⁢fj(ξ)gj(ζ)⁢η(ξ,ζ) in L∞. We can additionally arrange to have ⩽∑=j1k⁢fj(ξ)gj(ζ)⁢η(ξ,ζ) for every k. Now define :=Bj⁢F-1ζgj(ζ)Fv⟂ and :=Kj⁢F-1ξfj(ξ)Fvw(v)(-1Δv)-/12, where Fx is the Fourier transform in the variable x. These operators clearly have the desired properties, and we now need to check convergence of the sum (18), which is not immediately obvious if w is not bounded. First, note that :=K0⁢F-1ξ(+1ξ2)-/12Fvw(v)(-1Δv)-/12 is a compact operator on ⁢L2(V) and ⁢fn+1ξ2 is bounded. In order to exploit the fact that ⊗VK01 is compact in the first factor, we identify the operators on ⁢⊗⁢L2(V)L2(V⟂) with operators from ⁢L2(V) to ⁢L(⁢L2(V⟂),⁢L2(R⁢2d)) via :=⁢A(ψ)φ⊗⁢Aψφ. After this identification, ⊗VK01 defines a compact operator, since for any weakly convergent sequence ⇀ψkψ in ⁢L2(V) and ∈φ⁢L2(V⟂)

Math.text: norm@((K tensor-product _ V 1) * psi _ k * varphi - (K tensor-product 1) * psi * varphi) less= (norm@(K * psi _ k - K * psi)) _ (L ^ 2 * V) * (norm@(varphi)) _ (L ^ 2 * V ^ perpendicular-to)

para.p: Furthermore, the operators

Math.text: A _ m assign ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@(F ^ (- 1) * f _ j * xi * square-root@(1 + xi ^ 2) * g _ j * zeta * F)

para.p: converge to ⁢F-1η(ξ,ζ)+1ξ2F in the strong operator topology of⁢L(⁢L2(V),⁢L(⁢L2(V⟂),⁢L2(R⁢2d))), since for every ∈ψ⁢L2(V)

Math.text: (limit _ (m to infinity))@((norm@(A _ m * psi - (F ^ (- 1)) _ (open-interval@(xi, zeta)) * eta * open-interval@(xi, zeta) * square-root@(1 + xi ^ 2) * F _ (open-interval@(v, v ^ perpendicular-to)) * psi)) _ (L * open-interval@(L ^ 2 * V ^ perpendicular-to, L ^ 2 * R ^ (2 * d))))

(limit _ (m to infinity))@((norm@(A _ m * psi - (F ^ (- 1)) _ (open-interval@(xi, zeta)) * eta * open-interval@(xi, zeta) * square-root@(1 + xi ^ 2) * F _ (open-interval@(v, v ^ perpendicular-to)) * psi)) _ (L * open-interval@(L ^ 2 * V ^ perpendicular-to, L ^ 2 * R ^ (2 * d))))

absent = (limit _ (m to infinity))@((supremum _ (zeta element-of R ^ d))@((integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@((((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@(f _ j * xi * g _ j * zeta) - eta * open-interval@(xi, zeta)) * square-root@(1 + xi ^ 2) * widehat@(psi) * xi)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(xi)))) = 0

absent = (limit _ (m to infinity))@((supremum _ (zeta element-of R ^ d))@((integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@((((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@(f _ j * xi * g _ j * zeta) - eta * open-interval@(xi, zeta)) * square-root@(1 + xi ^ 2) * widehat@(psi) * xi)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(xi)))) = 0

para.p: as the integrand is bounded by ∈|⁢2η+1ξ2^ψ|2L1 and converges to zero, pointwise in ξ and uniformly in ζ. Thus, since =∑m⊗VKjBj⁢Am(⊗VK01), the sum in (18) converges in norm. To deduce the statement of lemma 4 from (18) we use use the formula

Math.text: absent = (1 / (2 * pi * i)) * (integral _ sigma)@(z ^ (- 1 / 2) * ((h _ 1 + h _ 2) - z) ^ (- 1) * (V * x _ 1 + V * x _ 2) * (2 * e - Delta _ x _ 1 - Delta _ x _ 2 - z) ^ (- 1) * differential-d@(z))
absent = (1 / (2 * pi * i)) * (integral _ sigma)@(z ^ (- 1 / 2) * ((h _ 1 + h _ 2) - z) ^ (- 1) * (V * x _ 1 + V * x _ 2) * (2 * e - Delta _ x _ 1 - Delta _ x _ 2 - z) ^ (- 1) * differential-d@(z))

para.p: where σ is the boundary of a sector in the right half plane >⁢Re(z)0 with σ∩{Im(z)=0}={e} and the integral converges in the operator norm. The argument we used to prove (18) also implies that ⁢(-1Δx1z)-/12V(x1)(-⁢2eΔx1Δx2z)-/12 is x1-semicompact, and thus (cf. Lemma 3)
is a compact operator for every ∈zσ. Now for ∈f⁢Lp(Rd) with >p⁢max(1,/d2) the Kato-Seiler-Simon inequality gives

Math.text: (norm@((1 - Delta _ x - z) ^ (- 1 / 2) * f * x * (1 - Delta _ x - z) ^ (- 1 / 2))) _ S _ p less= C * open-interval@(p, d) * (1 + (absolute-value@(z)) ^ 2) ^ ((d / 4) * p - 1 / 2) * (norm@(f)) _ (L ^ p)

para.p: Using the decomposition =V+f1f2 we see that the integral in (19) still converges in norm if multiplied by ⁢w(v)(-1Δv)-/12 from the right. Consequently, it defines a compact operator, so the difference between equations (11) and (18) is compact and the proof is complete.

Acknowledgment. We thank Laurent Bruneau, Vladimir Georgescu and Phan Thành Nam for useful discussions. We acknowledge financial support from the European Research Council under the European Community’s Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013 Grant Agreement MNIQS 258023).
